data.title: Where was The Canyon filmed?
data.meta_description:
Looking for a thrilling cinematic experience set against the backdrop of the Grand Canyon? Give The Canyon a try. This independent thriller from 2009, directed by Richard Harrah, boasts strong performances from Eion Bailey, Yvonne Strahovski of Chuck fame, and Will Patton.
The movie's narrative focuses on a just-married couple, Nick (Eion Bailey) and Lori (Yvonne Strahovski). Following an impromptu elopement in Las Vegas, they choose a mule tour of the Grand Canyon as their honeymoon trip. However, their anticipated blissful journey rapidly becomes a nightmare when their guide, Henry (Will Patton), misplaces their route in the extensive Arizona desert. This unfortunate mishap triggers a grueling battle for survival in the relentless wilderness.
Despite its gripping premise and picturesque settings, The Canyon received no awards and was met with poor reviews from critics. However, it has found some appreciation among viewers who were taken by the film's scenic landscapes and character development.

About The Canyon

The 2009 movie The Canyon featured a stunning backdrop of the majestic landscapes of the US Southwest. Filmed primarily in Arizona and Utah, this thrilling drama showcased some of the most beautiful and rugged terrain these two states offer. Shot over six weeks, The Canyon is a film that relies entirely on practical effects, with no usage of CGI. The wolves and rattlesnakes featured in the movie are real, adding an authentic touch to the action sequences. Scenes were shot in iconic locations such as the Antelope Canyon, Moab, Utah, and Williams, Arizona. These unique sites offer dramatic canyons, sandstone cliffs, colorful mesas and plateaus, lush forests, snow-covered peaks, and a rich variety of flora and fauna. A trip to these locations for The Canyon (2009) would be an amazing experience for any fan. Not only could you explore the actual places where scenes from the movie took place, but you could also take in the stunning natural beauty of each area, perfect for hiking or photography sessions. In addition to enjoying a spectacular view of nature's wonders, you will also find plenty of activities to do, such as horseback riding or whitewater rafting on some nearby rivers. All these activities are sure to make your visit truly unforgettable.

Nick (Eion Bailey) and Lori (Yvonne Strahovski) are fresh from their elopement. Seeking an adventurous honeymoon, they decide on a mule ride into the canyon, accompanied by their guide, Henry (Will Patton). The following day, they descend into the canyon. During their journey, Henry suggests a detour to ancient petroglyphs, located half a day's ride away. After some persuasion from Nick, Lori consents to the proposed journey. This scene, imbued with anticipation and the thrill of adventure, was filmed in Antelope Canyon, Utah. Antelope Canyon is a must-visit destination in the American Southwest, known for its water-carved sandstone curves that are beautifully illuminated by light shafts from above. Its ethereal beauty lends an authentic backdrop to the unfolding drama in The Canyon. However, Antelope Canyon is not just a stunning filming location but also a significant cultural site. Located on Navajo Nation land, it's governed by Navajo Nation rules. As such, visitors are required to book a tour with a Navajo guide to access Antelope Canyon. This ensures respect for the land and its cultural significance while allowing visitors to experience its breathtaking beauty. Access to Antelope Canyon is exclusively through guided tours, which can be booked from Las Vegas or the neighboring Page, AZ. If you're keen on witnessing the mesmerizing sunbeams that the canyon is famous for, plan your visit to Upper Antelope Canyon from mid-March to October.

After a day's hike, the newlywed couple (Yvonne Strahovski and Eion Bailey) find themselves at a dead end adorned with petroglyphs. The realization that they've been heading the wrong way pushes them to attempt a climb up the rock face, hoping to catch a signal on Lori's phone. This particular scene was captured in Moab, Utah. The exact filming location isn't disclosed, but Moab is renowned for its wealth of petroglyphs. Fans seeking to immerse themselves in the movie's environment can embark on a canyoneering trip in Moab, where they can encounter numerous petroglyphs. For instance, the Moonflower Canyon Petroglyphs are worth a visit. Easily accessible, these petroglyphs are located beside the road on a small section of the cliff wall, eliminating the need for a hike into the canyon. They're conveniently situated en route from Moab to Birthing Rock. The cliff wall along Potash Road by the Colorado River also houses the Potash Road Petroglyphs. These are scattered along the cliff, some high up and others closer to the ground. This variety adds an element of exploration and discovery for visitors. Travelers can reach Moab by private car. It takes approximately 3 hours to drive from Phoenix via Interstate 17 North. If coming from Las Vegas, the journey will take a little longer, around 3 hours and 20 minutes.

The Canyon provides viewers with stunning visuals of both Utah and Arizona landscapes. The filming locations for the film in Utah and Arizona have played an integral role in bringing this cinematic masterpiece to life. The breathtaking landscapes of these states, from the rugged canyons of Zion National Park to the iconic vistas of Monument Valley, have provided the perfect backdrop for the film's gripping narrative. With their stunning natural beauty and unparalleled cinematic charm, Utah and Arizona have genuinely added a touch of awe-inspiring magic to The Canyon, making it a visual and emotional journey like no other.
